Description: A pottery flask in the form of a hedgehog, modelled in the round, the ears indicated, standing on a domed rectangular base, with a double base-'ring' sunken within. From the top of the back rises a short neck with a flaring mouth and mouldings top and bottom; an angular handle with twisted grooving extends from the mouth to the lower back of the animal. Three-piece mould. Dark grey-brown Nile silt; overall black slip: Memphis Black Ware.
Curator's comments: Terracotta IV Donated: Henry Christy Trustees; once in the collection of the early traveller Lord Valentia. Ptolemaic, second or first century BC. Comparandum: See the cruder, red-slipped example Bayer-Niemeier 1988: no. 649, dated first to second century AD. Bibliog: Farebrother, Clark and Lye Sale Catalogue, Arley Castle, December 1852: lot 359; Glanville 1926: pl. xiv:2; von Droste zu Hülschoff 1980: pl. viii:84.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3742)
Previous owner: Previous owner/ex-collection: George Annesley, 2nd Earl of Mountnorris
